results.title: Dynasties
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Stephen Ramsey and Tim Clark
results.brief_description: Using rare archival footage, photographs and interviews, we are privy to family life and relationships of seven of Australia’s most powerful families. Nineteenth and twentieth century Australian history has been formed by some of the influence of these families - pastoralists, philanthropists, politicians and journalists - and some of their influence on society continues today. Families are: Murdoch, Downer, Wright, Myer, Durack, De Bortolis, and Macarthur. Two-disc set containing seven episodes from Series One of this fascinating ABC TV Documentary series. Narrated by William Zappa.

results.title: Dying to be thin
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “W5”.
An examination of the slimmer’s desease, anorexia nervosa. Through interviews with those who have, or have had the disorder, examines the psychological and societal pressures which induce young women to diet to the point of starvation.

results.title: Dutch oven cooking
results.brief_description: Illustrates the basic principles of fire building and Dutch oven cooking for hikers and campers. Emphasizes the care and precision which must be exercised when sharpening and using axes and knives; demonstrates the correct methods for chopping wood. Describes, step by step, the procedure for making a batch of biscuits including the preparation of the Dutch oven for baking.

results.title: Dustbins in the sky
results.creator_credit: Bob Thorpe, London Television Service and Mike Lockey
results.brief_description: Made for the television program “Perspective”, this documentary examined the growth of technology in the collection, transmission and dissemination of news, from early cinema newsreels to today’s satellite coverage.

results.title: Dust to dust
results.brief_description: Tells the story of a small town in northern NSW and the effects of asbestos mining there. The people estimate that three-quarters of the workers have died or are sick from exposure to asbestos. In presenting their story the film raises issues regarding occupational health in general.

results.title: Durga puja in Calcutta
results.creator_credit: Calcutta Film Society and Mriganka Sekhar Ray
results.brief_description: The monsoon is over…in Bengal it is time for the festival of Durga Puja, goddess of war, militant aspect of Parvati, consort of Shiva. Celebrations praise Durga’s victory over the buffalo demon Mahisasura symbolising triumph of good over evil. The film is an impressionistic view of this festival.

results.title: Durer and the renaissance
results.brief_description: Part of the Art History series, describes the life and work of Albrecht Durer, German painter and engraver, and his part in connecting the artistic development in Italy with that of northern Europe.

results.title: Duplicating and manuscript
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Advanced Typing”.
Demonstrates the correct methods of making masters for duplicating machine use, correcting mistakes on a stencil, the use of the illuminated drawing board for tracing lines, making hectograph masters, correcting mistakes when using hectograph ribbon, or carbon, use of electromatic hectograph machine, use of various types of duplicating machines, and typing manuscripts with footnotes. Centering on a typewriter improving characters or marks that do not appear on the keyboard, and reading proof readers’ marks are also explained.

results.title: Duplex
results.creator_credit: David Price, Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television and Michaela French
results.brief_description: Two elderly neighbours Elsie (Esme Melville) and Dora (Margaret Ricketts) are isolated by the limitations that their old age brings. Both are lonely but fail to strike up a friendship as personal obstacles like pride get in the way. Slowly, slowly, Elsie’s determination breaks Dora’s stubborn resistance and the two begin anew as friends. Written, directed and edited by Michaela French.
